author: Special Correspondent
text:
A US defence policy expert has opined that it was mature on the part of India to have shown restraint from being provoked during the aftermath of the terror attacks on an air force base at Pathankot in Punjab.

Interacting with journalists at the US Consulate General here, Mark A. Bucknam, Professor, National Security Strategy in National War College in Washington DC, said the incident inside an air force base was “very troubling”.

Lauding India for not allowing itself to be played into the hands of forces that intended to disturb efforts in the peace-making process, Mr. Bucknam said India had maintained “great show of restraint.”

Clarifying that his opinion did not represent the stand of the US government or National War College, Mr. Bucknam, who had spent nearly four years at the Pentagon, replied in the negative when asked whether hot pursuit in this case was an option.

While commenting on including Japan as a permanent partner in the ‘Malabar’ naval exercises involving India and the US since October last year, he said the decision would help Washington DC in coordinating with multiple partners at a time during emergency situations.

China’s tough stand

When asked for his opinion over China’s tough stand on navigation in the South China Sea, he said the US wanted stability in the region.

“The US is not trying to contain China. The US cannot contain China. The US is only interested in the peaceful rise of China.”

However, it maintained its stand over freedom of navigation on the high seas, including the South China Sea, he said.

Says hot pursuit in this case was not an option
title: ‘India showed great restraint after Pathankot’
